physical_examinations.relevant_findings: A 33-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and ascites. Admitted; abdominal ultrasound showed ascites (exudate) and intestinal wall thickening.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The patient improved spontaneously after discontinuation of contraceptives.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: A 37-year-old woman experienced recurrent laryngeal edema after starting oral contraceptives 15 days prior to her first episode.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Symptoms improved after stopping contraceptives and subsequently she remained asymptomatic post tubal ligation.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: A 58-year-old woman reported facial angioedema episodes correlated with oral contraceptive use.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Symptoms resolved upon cessation of the contraceptives.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: A 26-year-old woman had facial angioedema requiring hospitalization, responded to intravenous tranexamic acid.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Similar, though milder episodes experienced during her first pregnancy.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: A 32-year-old woman reported recurrent abdominal pain with episodes of facial angioedema starting 12 years ago, triggered by stress and minor trauma.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Asymptomatic after the withdrawal of oral contraceptives.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: A 37-year-old pregnant woman had recurrent angioedema affecting several areas since age 15, including upper airway involvement.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Severity increased with changes in oral contraceptives but improved after stopping them.
